instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SYS_ONEWIRE: What is SYS_ONEWIRE? This is a bidirectional communication line between the system management controller(SMC) and the charger that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC. This must be working for the light to come on on the magsafe charger. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC: What is SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC? SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC is a voltage that is created if SMC_BC_ACOK & PP3V42_G3H are both present that powers the chipset for the onewire circuit that allows the SMC to talk to the charger on the SYS_ONEWIRE line. This is necessary for the magsafe charger to have a light on it. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ADAPTER_SENSE: What is ADAPTER_SENSE? This is a line between the onewire circuit and the magsafe charger where the magsafe charger can talk to the SMC(system management controller) on the SYS_ONEWIRE line..
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.5V_S4: What is 5V_S4? This is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S4” – when you see this, assume the person typing it meant to type “PP5V_S4”.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: Ok so I got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that has a slightly corroded lcd connector and the microphone connector was burned. I have PP3V42 and PPBUS G3H is 12.56V but no green light. There is no corrosion by the SMC or ISL. Could there still be an SMC issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
Check first <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> circuit.
Post some voltages there.
Did you try known good DCIN board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> is at 3.41V.
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK_VCC</SIGNAL> in 3.42V

I will try another DC IN board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: When I checked the power rails I have them up to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>, which is at 0V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: oh yeah and the board is drawing 19mA. Tried a different DC In board but nothing changed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
"Check first <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> circuit."
I was expecting all <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages...

Reball SMC, corrosion could affected its solders.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: Oh, ok. I'll get all <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> voltages. I will also reball the SMC

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: So the only other voltage for <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_SENSE</SIGNAL>, Which is at 3.42V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
Looks like <SIGNAL>SYS_ONEWIRE</SIGNAL> circuit is closed; just missing communication.
Report back after SMC reballed.
If still the same, change it.

I hope you already tried known good Magsafe 2 charger...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: Yeah i am using an Apple Original Magsafe2 purchased from Best Buy.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: Will Report back after SMC reball...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: Reballed SMC and no change. I think I stated before that I do not get a green light but I do get a MagSafe light. I?m still getting PPBUS, PP3V42 and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>. I?m missing the two ?X239? rails in the G3H list, But I think one has to do with trackpad not being plugged in. Still not getting <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> either

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: Replaced SMC, now drawing 26mA vs the 19mA from before

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
"I think I stated before that I do not get a green light but I do get a MagSafe light"
Do you mean amber light present on the Magsafe?
That is fine, why do you want to get green light?
I was supposing you don't get light on Magsafe at all.
Magsafe should switch from green to amber very fast, even no battery connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: Yeah, that Is what I meant. I said in my first post No light but I was mistaken. I get a green/orange light.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
Then ONEWIRE circuit is OK.
What else problem do you have on the board?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: Missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
You must get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> prior <SIGNAL>5V_S4</SIGNAL>.

"the power rails I have them up to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>"
I was supposing <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is present...

Post <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>.
Be sure to use original Magsafe 2 85W charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: Oh shoot, yeah just realized I am missing an S5 rail, sorry. Of course I wouldn't get <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>... late night. Will post results shortly

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>: 3.40v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>: 0v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL>: 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>: 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
Original Magsafe 2 charger 60/85W for sure???

Post <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> basic voltages; 23, 12, 13, 22, 29, 21.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: I am so sorry I wasted your time on this one. I ignored the basic rule to pay attention to corroded components, or components with gray end caps. I found another forum post where the person had the same problem on an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. The <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> rail was shorted. They measured the coil (L7560) and found that a cap or two was shorted. So I decided to measure the same coil on my board well lo and behold <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> was short, by the same caps. they were <CAPACITOR>C3280</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C3281</CAPACITOR> respectively, and are located close to the LCD connector. The end caps were gray but didn't look too bad. well once I took them off, the short was gone. Put some replacements from a donor and now we have fan spin and a ? folder. i should have known better since these two caps are tied to the mic connector which burnt up. lesson learned.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
You've repaired it and learned a lesson too.
It is not waste of time, nor even for me. :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: So this one is still working but I have no backlight. I have an image and the fuse is not blown. On <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> <SIGNAL>BKL_EN_L</SIGNAL> is 12.54V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
Post U770 voltages, 5, 18, 17, 15, 16, 11.
Also check diode mode to ground at both A/K pins of <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>; w/ and w/o LCD connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
<DIODE>D7710</DIODE>:

W/LCD: A= .884V K=1.233V

W/O LCD: A=.887V  K=1.235V

<CHIP>U7700</CHIP>:
Pin 5: 5.144V
Pin 11: 12.38V
Pin 15: 5.142V
Pin 16: 5.142V
Pin 17: 0V
Pin 18: 5.142V

I also observed when measuring L8300  when turning on board it measures 5V here and then after like 10 seconds it drops to 0.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
In the time you have 5V at pins 28-30/J8300, check if <SIGNAL>LCD_HPD_CONN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> go both high.

"Put some replacements from a donor and now we have fan spin and a ? folder."
Did you get image and backlight that time?
And now nothing at all?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: I'll check those next. At the time I could not tell if I had an image or not, I had to replace the LCD connector on the board due to corroded/missing pins. I for sure have an image though.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: i get 0v on both

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: So I timed how long it takes for the 5V to show up on Pins 28-30 on J8300 and it is about 10 seconds before it comes on then stays fr about 10 seconds before dropping to 0. I noticed on the two tests you wanted me to do the millivolt digit on my DMM would dance between 1 and zero at the 10 second mark, then stop.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
If these lines stay low, PCH cannot recognize LCD.
Try known good compatible LCD assembly.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: Ok, tried two different screens, still no go

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
At least <SIGNAL>LCD_HPD_CONN</SIGNAL> should go high (2.5V), when you have 5V at J8300.
If not, bad video cable, or LCD panel.
Could also be a problem with LCD connector, if you already detected corrosion there.
Check all solders and traces...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: Yeah I tried two different panels after plugging them into other boards.  Should the 5V stay on? Or is it supposed to come on, then tuen off? I guess  I could grab a working board and check.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
5V should come on for few seconds even if not LCD connected.
But it only remains on if PCH detects LCD.
That is only possible if <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> comes on; it requires 5V above mentioned.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: LOL I think I measured it without LCD... I?ll remeasure with LCD

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: Ok, so with test LCD 5V is steady on L8300 and I get 3.3V on pin 2 of <CAPACITOR>C8353</CAPACITOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: I'm also getting 51.81V on pin 2 of <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message: I fixed it!!!! don't know how I missed it, but the two vias for pin 1 (<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>) were broken. FIlled the one that was barely broken with solder and ran a wire for the other. oh boy what a troll this was. Now all I have to do is wait for new mic connector to come, run a new pad for that and this will be a fully working board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> problens
threads.message:
"51.81V on pin 2 of <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>"
That was the sign; broken LED strips circuit...
